questions.question: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the hydration and transparencyof the cornea?
questions.explanation: The hydration level and transparency of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelialcells of the cornea.The endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relativelydehydrated state. This helps maintain corneal transparency. Endothelial cells decrease in numberwith age. If the cornea becomes overhydrated, it begins to scatter light and gradually begins tolose its transparencyOther factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows:•Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory)•The peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)•• Avascularity of the cornea•A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressureThe different layers of the cornea are as follows:⚫ Epithelium• Bowman's membrane•Stroma (substantia propria)• Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)• Descemet's membrane• Endothelium

questions.question: What is the average density of corneal endothelial cells?

options.C: 3500-4000 cells/mm²2500-3000 cells/mm²Question 4:Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of micro-cornea be made?a) 8 mmb) 9 mm132c) 10 mm

questions.explanation: The density of corneal endothelial cells in adults is about 2500-3000 cells/mm².142Variation in corneal endothelial density with age:• At birth- 3,500-4,000 cells/mm2 at birth•• Young adults- 2500-3000 cells/mm²• Old age (about 80 years)- 2000 cells/mm²Corneas stored in eye banks are assessed for their quality and viability using a variety ofparameters. Donor tissues are screened for stress lines, mechanical trauma, scarring, cornealedema, and infiltrates that could indicate poor tissue quality. They are further evaluated forthickness and endothelial cell density (a surrogate for endothelial function) which are importantdeterminants of successful graft transplantation.Endothelial cell density (ECD) and morphology are assessed using a specular microscope or by abright-field/phase-contrast light microscope.Note: The number of cells decreases at about 0.6% per year, and the neighboring cells enlarge tofill the space as the cells cannot regenerate. At a density of about 500 cells/mm2, corneal edemadevelops and transparency is impaired. This is known as critical endothelial density.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms are capable of invading the intact cornea?
questions.explanation: Gonococcus can invade an intact cornea.Organisms that can penetrate the intact epithelium of the cornea can be remembered with themnemonic- CHANNELS••Corynebacterium diphtheriaHaemophilus influenza; Haemophilus aegypticus• Neisseria gonorrhea; Neisseria meningitidis• Listeria•Shigella

questions.question: A patient with a history of uncomplicated cataract surgery 1 year back, presents with pain,redness, and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer wasnoted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon anda moderate flare reaction. A smear from the ulcerated area is likely to demonstrate which ofthe following organisms?
questions.explanation: Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typicallycaused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile.Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of thecornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion.Risk factors include both surgical and non-surgical ocular trauma, dry eye, chronic cornealdisease, immune alterations and contact lenses.An examination may reveal the following signs:• Swelling of lids and blepharospasm•Conjunctival hyperemia•Ciliary congestion, hypopyon and anterior chamber flare reaction• IridocyclitisImage given below shows ulcus serpens.144EyeRounds.org

questions.question: A young woman presents with sudden onset, rapidly progressing ocular pain, photophobia,and blurred vision in her right eye for 1 day. A deep, 4 mm diameter corneal ulcer,surrounded by stromal infiltrates was visualized. The anterior chamber has small amounts ofmucopurulent discharge. She mentions using a cosmetic contact lens which she forgot toremove before sleeping 2 days ago. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation: The sudden onset and rapid progression of ocular symptoms and ulceration in this patient alongwith the history of improper contact lens usage are suggestive of a Pseudomonas infection.Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common gram-negative organism isolated from cornealulcers and is a frequent cause of contact lens-associated keratitis. Other risk factors includechlorinated swimming pools, hot tubs, ventilators, nebulizer, and vaporizer solutions, andophthalmic solution bottles.Pseudomonas keratitis has a rapid and fulminant course if left untreated and are associated with aworse visual prognosis than that caused by most other common bacterialpathogens. Pseudomonas spp. can cause corneal perforation in just 48 hours. Treatment is mainlyby topical NSAIDs and topical antipseudomonal antibiotic eye drops such as tobramycin 1.3% andfluoroquinolone eye drops.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: A young woman comes with sudden onset ocular pain, tearing, and photophobia in the lefteye. You suspect a bacterial corneal ulcer. What concentration of cephazolin drops would youprescribe for this patient?Corneal Ulcer Dr MBOUSSOU Yoan
questions.explanation: The concentration of fortified cephazolin used to treat uncomplicated bacterial keratitis is 5% (50mg/mL)Treatment of uncomplicated bacterial keratitis:• Antibiotic eyedrops (broad-spectrum)• If not responding, fortified antibiotic eye drops are used• Fortified cephazolin (5%)• Fortified tobramycin (1.3%)⚫ Fortified vancomycin (5%)•145•Cycloplegic drugs- Preferably 1% atropine eye ointment or drops to prevent pain due to ciliaryspasm. Also, it prevents the development of posterior synechiae.• Oral vitamin A and vitamin C help in the healing of the epithelium•Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugsManagement of non-healing ulcers:• Debridement• Chemical cauterization- 10–20% trichloroacetic acid, carbolic acid•Conjunctival flappingManagement of impending perforation:• Decrease intraocular pressure (IOP) by antiglaucoma drugs•Tissue adhesive glue such as cyanoacrylate•Bandage contact lens• No strain

questions.question: A non-sterile hypopyon is seen in
questions.explanation: Fungal keratitis can cause non-sterile hypopyon.Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anteriorchamber without perforation.Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause.Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer is fixed, non-sterile and contains fungal filaments.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago,resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the mostlikely pathology?134
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of theeye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer.Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetativematter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids andantibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis.Mycotic keratitis can be caused by• Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium• Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus•Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and BlastomycesTypically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. Thesymptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain,lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes.146A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs:•Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin.•⚫ Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epitheliumWessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immunecomplexes•Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer• Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterilehypopyon)• Perforation is rare•Corneal vascularization is usually absent.A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followedby clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings.The image below depicts a fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion.DAILYROUNDSOther options:Option A: Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris up to the parsplicata of the ciliary body. Infectious uveitis can be caused by the exogenous entry of theorganisms following penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcer, and post-intaocularoperations.Acute anterior uveitis presents with symptoms of pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blurring ofvision and redness of the eye. Signs of anterior uveitis include:•-Aqueous flare It is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis, it occurs following the leakage ofprotein particles into the aqueous humor.• Keratic precipitates(KP) - These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. They are proteinaceouscellular deposits at the back of the cornea arranged in a triangular fashion. These include muttonfat KP's as seen in granulomatous uveitis and granular KP's of non granulomatous uveitis.147• Iris nodules: typically occur in granulomatous uveitis. Koppe's nodules are at the pupillaryborder and Busacca's nodules are situated near the collarette.Option C: Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva of which the bacterialconjunctivitis is the most common. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by markedconjunctival hyperemia, swelling of the conjunctiva (chemosis), edematous eyelids, stickingtogether of lid margins and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.The image shows a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis.Option D: Corneal laceration: Partial corneal laceration or lamellar corneal laceration occurs froma blunt trauma and is treated by patching and antibiotics.

questions.question: A farmer presents with blurring of vision in his left eye. He has a history of injury with a bushto the same eye while working. An ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Slit-lampexamination shows infiltrates in the corneal stroma in a circular fashion. Which type ofhypersensitivity reaction causes these infiltrates?
questions.explanation: The given clinical situation points towards a fungal corneal ulcer and the infiltrates of stroma in acircular fashion are suggestive of the immune ring of Wessely. This immune ring is due to type 3hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as aresult of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws theimmune cells, inciting further inflammation.The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.148

questions.question: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal ulcer?

options.B: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye

questions.explanation: Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.The signs of a fungal ulcer include:• Irregular margins of the ulcer.• Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.• An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immunecomplexes.••Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion ofthe fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

questions.question: Steroids are contraindicated in
questions.explanation: Steroids are contraindicated in fungal corneal ulcerSteroids make the fungi facultative pathogens when they are otherwise symbiotic saprophytes.Therefore, the use of these drugs predisposes the patients to fungal infections and perforation.

questions.question: 135A 41-year-old female presented with a one-month history of photophobia and foreign bodysensation in her right eye. A slit-lamp examination showed a corneal ulcer. The culture of thecorneal scrapings grew a filamentous organism identified as a fusarium species. What wouldbe the drug of choice in this case?
questions.explanation: This patient with a one-month history of eye foreign body sensations and photophobia and slitlamp exam showing an ulcer that had fusarium growth most likely has a fungal corneal ulcer.Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice for filamentous fungal keratitis caused by149fusariam species.Surface debridement is also done as it helps to remove slough, reduce the load of infection andenhances drug penetration. Amphotericin B is particularly effective against yeasts but lesseffective against filamentous fungi. Also, its penetration through an intact epithelium is less thannatamycin.Amphotericin B is the first agent of choice against yeasts. Amphotericin B (0.15%) drops can beconsidered alone or in combination with natamycin in refractory cases.Treatment of specific fungal corneal ulcers:Topical antifungal dropsAspergillus and Fusarium- Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B, fluconazole (0.2%)• Candida- Amphotericin B (0.15%) or econazole (1%)Systemic antifungals such as itraconazole and voriconazole are used for severe non-respondingcases or if the location of the ulcer is near the limbus or if there is a risk of perforation leading toendophthalmitis.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of the given condition?
questions.explanation: The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. Corneal guttata are notseen in HSV infection. They are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on theposterior surface of Descemet's membrane. It is a feature of corneal dystrophies.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?136

options.A: It is related to Hutchinson's triad
options.B: There is usually a history of primary HSV infection as a child
options.D: High dose topical acyclovir is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation: The image shows a unilateral painful, vesicular rash suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus(HZO) caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) within the ophthalmicnerve. Neurotrophic keratitis is a complication of HZV infection.Keratitis occurs due to corneal nerve damage by the virus leading to decreased sensation, frequentinfections, persistent epithelial defect, thinning and even perforation.Corneal lesions in HZO (zoster keratitis):•Epithelium- superficial punctate keratitis and pseudo-dendritic ulcer• Stroma- nummular keratitis and disciform keratitisOther ocular lesions in herpes zoster:• Uveitis⚫ Episcleritis and scleritis••Conjunctivitis• Acute retinal necrosis• Secondary glaucoma150• Anterior segment necrosis and pthisis bulbiOther options:Option A: Hutchinson's rule is related to herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It states that if the tip of thenose is involved, there will be a significant risk of ocular involvement. This is due to theinvolvement of the nasociliary nerve. Hutchinson's triad is seen in congenital syphilis.Option B: There is primary HZV infection (chickenpox/varicella) not HSV infection.Option D: Systemic acyclovir is the treatment of choice; not topical antiviral drops. Oral acyclovir800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days, ideally initiated within 72 h of the onset of symptoms is theusual regimen.The image shows Hutchinson's sign in a patient with herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy presented with blurred vision, photophobia, and increasing pain in his righteye. He has been using contact lenses for the past 2 years. He mentions swimming with hiscousins 2 weeks back in a local pond. A close-up image of the eye is given below. What is themost likely explanation?137DAILYROUNDS
questions.explanation: The history of a patient with contact lens use with swimming in freshwater ponds with the imagedepicting a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) makes acanthamoeba keratitis the likely diagnosis.Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare protozoal infection of the cornea. It is more common in softcontact lens users. The organism exists either as active, motile trophozoites or dormant,double-walled cysts. Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub whilewearing contact lenses, homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standinggroundwater etc.Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as ringlesion (most common), pseudo-dendrites and as a reticular pattern.Diagnosis:• Confocal microscopy - may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epitheliumand double-walled cyst forms151•Histopathology - double-walled cysts are seen on H& E. Other stainsfor Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome orperiodic acid-Schiff-• Culture Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. coli plated on a non-nutrient agar

questions.question: A 39-year-old contact lens user with a corneal ulcer, showing no improvement to tobramycindrops, was referred to a tertiary care centre. Corneal biopsy revealed double-walled cystswithin the stroma. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: This patient with a corneal ulcer whose biopsy showed double walled cysts in the stroma mostlikely has acanthamoeba keratitis. Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the treatment ofchoice for acanthamoeba keratitis.Combination therapy with chlorhexidine is most effective against trophozoites and cysts. This isrecommended as the first line of therapy.Other topical anti-amoebic agents:• Diamidines- Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %), Hexamidine••Aminoglycosides- Neomycin, Paramomycin• Imidazoles- Clotrimazole, Miconazole

questions.question: Which of the following does not cause interstitial keratitis?
questions.explanation: Diphtheria is not a cause of interstitial keratitis.Interstitial keratitis is a non-ulcerating, inflammatory reaction of the corneal stroma that ischaracterized by non-suppurative infiltration and often stromal vascularization. The epitheliumand endothelium are not affected. Scarring due to stromal inflammation and vascularization, ininterstitial keratitis, can result in decreased vision.Interstitial keratitis (IK) is a common endpoint of any keratitis that predominantly involves thecorneal stroma. So there is a wide range of potential etiologies.Treatment for IK typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids, as well as appropriatesystemic medications for the associated systemic disease.Immune-mediated etiologiesCogan syndrome:Interstitialkeratitis + deafness + vertigoSarcoidosis Mycosis fungoideSInfectious etiologiesBacterial causes:Syphilis; Lyme diseaseTuberculosis; Leprosy Brucellosis; Leptospirosis.Viral causes: Herpes simplex (HSV), Herpes zoster (VZV) Epstein-Barr (EBV), mumps, rubella (measles)influenza, andvacciniaParasitic causes:leishmaniasisonchocerciasistrypanosomiasisplasmodiumacanthamoeba152

questions.question: Which of the following infections is classically associated with salmon patch appearance ofthe cornea?
questions.explanation: Salmon patch appearance of the cornea is classically associated with syphilitic infection.This is because, syphilis causes deep vascularization of the cornea, leading to a radial bundle ofbrush-like vessels.Stages of interstitial keratitis in congenital syphilis:.Progressive stage - ground-glass appearance.• Florid stage - salmon patch appearance• Stage of regression - ghost vesselsSalmon Patch appearance

questions.question: 138A patient with recurrent corneal epithelial erosions is diagnosed with limbal stem celldeficiency. She has been enrolled on a research trial for corneal epithelial stem celltransplant. All are markers that can be used to identify stem cells from an ex-vivo cultureexcept?
questions.explanation: Connexin 50 is not a limbal stem-cell marker.The major markers proposed for epithelial stem cells can be categorized into at least three groups:••••.Nuclear proteins such as transcription factor p63Cell membrane or transmembrane proteins• Integrins (integrin B1, α6, and α9),Receptors (epidermal growth factor [EGF] receptor and transferrin receptor CD71)• Drug-resistance transporters (ABCG2—a universal stem cell marker)• Cytoplasmic proteins such as•Cytokeratins (cytokeratin 14 - exclusively at LSC)153• Alpha-enolase

questions.question: For her final year thesis, an ophthalmology resident is studying endothelial cell loss due tophacoemulsification surgery. The image is taken during the pre-op evaluation of one of thecataract patients. What does this show?
questions.explanation: The given image is a specular microscopy view of endothelial cells of different shapes(pleomorphism) and large surface area (polymegathism). These are indicators of endothelialdysfunction.A normal endothelium has a regular hexagonal shape. Because these cells are terminallydifferentiated cells, they do not divide, and when they die, the remaining cells have to stretch tocover more area, resulting in polymegathism and pleomorphism.Taking an endothelial cell count can be helpful before taking patients up for cataract or refractivesurgery so that any potential endothelial dysfunction or thinning is recognized before they havethe surgical intervention.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of herpetic keratitis?139
questions.explanation: Corneal guttata are seen in corneal dystrophy.Peripheral guttata are seen in old age-Hassall-Henle bodies. Central guttata, on the other hand,are found in Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

questions.question: A corneal foreign body was removed from a 53-year-old man. He was sent home withchloramphenicol and steroid eye drops. Two days later he came back with a corneal ulcer anda hypopyon. The ulcer scraping under microscopy revealed branched septate hyphae. What isthe likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given history of trauma and worsening with antibiotic-steroid drops suggests a fungal cornealulcer. Out of the given options, Aspergillus is the fungus with branched septate hyphae.Clinically, fungi are classified on a morphological basis into filamentous, yeast, anddimorphic forms:• Filamentous organisms are multicellular with branched hyphae. It can be septate or aseptate.•Septate filamentous organisms, such as Fusarium and Aspergillus, have hyphae that are dividedby cell walls.• Non-septate filamentous fungi, include Mucor and Rhizopus..Yeasts, such as Candida and Cryptococcus, are unicellular fungi that reproduce by budding, butin tissue, they might develop elongated buds (pseudohyphae).•Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, and Blastomyces demonstrate both a yeastphase that occurs in tissues and a mycelial phase that appears on culture media and saprophyticsurfaces.Image: Branched septate hyphae of Aspergillus spp.154

questions.question: Corneal sensation is lost in
questions.explanation: Corneal sensation is lost in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.The pathognomic feature of viral keratitis is decreased corneal sensation. Decreased cornealsensation is also seen in diabetes mellitus and leprosy.155
